title: Tom Hammond
text:
Thomas Taylor Hammond (born May 10, 1944) is an American <a href="Sports%20commentator">sportscaster</a>. Hammond is primarily known for his work with <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC Sports</a> from 1984 to the present. Hammond is one of the network's staple on-air presenters, along with <a href="Bob%20Costas">Bob Costas</a> and <a href="Dan%20Hicks%20%28sportscaster%29">Dan Hicks</a>. 
Hammond is best known for his coverage of <a href="Thoroughbred%20Racing%20on%20NBC">Thoroughbred Racing on NBC</a>, coverage of <a href="Notre%20Dame%20Football%20on%20NBC">Notre Dame Football on NBC</a> from 1992 to 2012 and his coverage of the <a href="NFL%20on%20NBC">NFL on NBC</a> from 1985 to 2011.
Hammond also served as the play-by-play announcer for NBC's coverage of <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> at each <a href="Summer%20Olympic%20Games">Summer Olympics</a> from 1992 to 2016. He also announced the speed skating events during the <a href="2018%20Winter%20Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a>.
Early career.
Hammond earned a B.S. in animal science in 1967 from the <a href="University%20of%20Kentucky">University of Kentucky</a>, specializing in equine genetics and following in the footsteps of his grandfather, Thomas Poe Cooper, a former dean of the UK College of Agriculture and a former Acting President of UK. He began his career with WVLK Radio, where he was news and sports director. In 1970 and for the next 10 years, he was sports director for WLEX-TV. In 1980, he was named a play-by-play announcer for <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> basketball games.
Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, he served as a sales announcer at the Keeneland Thoroughbred Sales and at thoroughbred horse sales in 16 other states. He is recognized as a specialist and national expert on thoroughbred pedigrees.
Hammond was the lead play-by-play commentator for <a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> men's basketball broadcasts by <a href="TVS%20Television%20Network">TVS</a> (1980–1983), <a href="Lorimar%20Sports%20Network">SPI/Lorimar</a> (1984–1986) and <a href="Raycom%20Sports">Raycom Sports</a> (formerly <a href="Lincoln%20Financial%20Media%23Lincoln%20Financial%20Sports">Lincoln Financial Sports</a> and <a href="Jefferson%20Pilot%20Sports">Jefferson Pilot Sports</a>) from 1987 until 2009. Hammond had known his <a href="color%20commentator">color commentator</a> on the Lincoln Financial broadcasts, <a href="Larry%20Conley">Larry Conley</a>, since junior high school.
NBC Sports.
Hammond's tenure at NBC began in 1984, when he was named as a co-host of the inaugural <a href="Breeders%27%20Cup">Breeders' Cup</a> alongside <a href="Dick%20Enberg">Dick Enberg</a>. It was supposed to be a one-shot deal for Hammond, but network execs were so impressed, he ended up getting a long-term contract. He was the main host of the network's <a href="thoroughbred%20racing">thoroughbred racing</a> coverage until <a href="Mike%20Tirico">Mike Tirico</a> took over in 2017.
Hammond's duties at NBC expanded to covering many other sports. He was the network's play-by-play voice for its coverage of Notre Dame football alongside analyst <a href="Mike%20Mayock">Mike Mayock</a>. He was also the lead play-by-play man for "<a href="The%20AFL%20on%20NBC">The AFL on NBC</a>". Hammond also has been very much involved in NBC's <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a> coverage. At the <a href="Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a>, Hammond served as the chief commentator for <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a>, a position for which he debuted at the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, where his broadcast partner that year was <a href="O.%20J.%20Simpson">O. J. Simpson</a>. Hammond has since said that, prior to the <a href="O.%20J.%20Simpson%20murder%20case">O. J. Simpson murder case</a>, he and Simpson were great friends and got along well. Hammond also commentates on other track and field events shown on NBC. At the <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>, Hammond is the main commentator for <a href="figure%20skating">figure skating</a> and <a href="ice%20dancing">ice dancing</a>. Hammond is sort of unique in that, unlike most of his NBC Sports colleagues, he does not live in or around the <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> area, opting to stay in his hometown of Lexington, a decision he made during his early days at NBC. Hammond isn't alone in this choice; despite being a New York native himself, Costas lives in <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>, Missouri.
Hammond was considered the leading play-by-play candidate when NBC won the bidding for <a href="NBC%20Sunday%20Night%20Football">Sunday night NFL coverage</a> beginning with the 2006 season, but ended up losing out to former <a href="ABC%20Sports">ABC</a> announcer <a href="Al%20Michaels">Al Michaels</a> after the latter signed with NBC. Hammond teamed with <a href="Cris%20Collinsworth">Cris Collinsworth</a> to call the secondary Saturday Wild Card playoff game for NBC each year, including in January 2007, in 2008, and in 2009, but teamed with <a href="Joe%20Gibbs">Joe Gibbs</a> and <a href="Joe%20Theismann">Joe Theismann</a> for the Wild Card playoff game in January 2010, as Cris Collinsworth partnered with Al Michaels in the 2009 season due to the retirement of <a href="John%20Madden%20%28American%20football%29">John Madden</a> after the 2008 season. Hammond also filled in for <a href="Bryant%20Gumbel">Bryant Gumbel</a> as play-by-play announcer on the <a href="NFL%20Network">NFL Network</a>'s <a href="Run%20to%20the%20Playoffs">December 13, 2007 game</a> featuring the Denver Broncos and Houston Texans on "Thursday Night Football", once more teaming with Collinsworth. 
Hammond and Collinsworth also serve as the announcing team on the "<a href="Madden%20NFL">Madden NFL</a>" video game in 2009 and 2010. and "<a href="Madden%20NFL%2010">Madden NFL 10</a>". The game is notable for how he mispronounced the name of then-Oakland Raiders cornerback <a href="Nnamdi%20Asomugha">Nnamdi Asomugha</a>.
Hammond's work at NBC also included play-by-play commentary for "<a href="NBA%20on%20NBC">The NBA on NBC</a>" and "<a href="NFL%20on%20NBC">The NFL on NBC</a>". He called <a href="gymnastics">gymnastics</a>, <a href="figure%20skating">figure skating</a>, the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20Association">WNBA</a>, the <a href="Orange%20Bowl%20%28game%29">Orange Bowl</a> and college basketball.
Health issues.
Over the past few years, Hammond's health has somewhat deteriorated. On March 24, 2001, under two months before NBC was supposed to broadcast the <a href="Kentucky%20Derby">Kentucky Derby</a> for the very first time, he underwent an operation for <a href="diverticulitis">diverticulitis</a>, a disease that affects the <a href="Colon%20%28anatomy%29">colon</a>. During the surgery, a portion of Hammond's colon was removed. However, even with the short amount of time between the Derby and his operation, Hammond managed to get healthy enough to make his dream of broadcasting his home state's most famous sporting event become a reality on May 5, 2001.
Hammond wasn't so lucky in October 2002, when he underwent open-heart surgery. He ended up missing the Breeders' Cup that year. Bob Costas took Hammond's place at the hosting desk. It was the only Breeders' Cup Hammond was not a part of until 2006, when ESPN had their first year of coverage.
Personal life.
Hammond and his wife, Sheilagh, have three grown children, sons David and Christopher and daughter Ashley. David has followed in his father's footsteps, becoming a radio commentator for <a href="Syracuse%20University">Syracuse University</a>'s basketball and football teams and working as a play-by-play announcer for "The AFL on NBC".
Honors and awards.
Hammond has been awarded horse race broadcasting's top honor, the Eclipse Award (Media category), in 1984 and 1996. He was awarded an Emmy Award for coverage of the 1992 Breeder's Cup. He also won Emmys for sports broadcasting in 1988 (men's and women's basketball), 1992 (Olympics coverage of track and field and diving), and 1996 (Olympics Track and Field).
He was the first recipient of the annual Outstanding Kentuckian Award given by the A.B. Chandler Foundation, is a charter member of the Lafayette High School Hall of Fame and has been inducted into the Kentucky Journalism Hall of Fame, University of Kentucky Hall of Distinguished Alumni and Kentucky Sports Hall of Fame. Inducted into the KY Pro Football HOF in 2006.
